Attacks¶

FGSM¶

class torchattacks.attacks.fgsm.FGSM(model, eps=0.007)[source]¶

FGSM in the paper ‘Explaining and harnessing adversarial examples’ [https://arxiv.org/abs/1412.6572]

Parameters:
  • model (nn.Module) – model to attack.
  • eps (float) – strength of the attack or maximum perturbation. (DEFALUT : 0.007)
Shape:
  • images: \((N, C, H, W)\) where N = number of batches, C = number of channels, H = height and W = width. It must have a range [0, 1].
  • labels: \((N)\) where each value \(y_i\) is \(0 \leq y_i \leq\) number of labels.
  • output: \((N, C, H, W)\).
Examples::
>>> attack = torchattacks.FGSM(model, eps=0.007)
>>> adv_images = attack(images, labels)
forward(images, labels)[source]¶

Overridden.

DeepFool¶

class torchattacks.attacks.deepfool.DeepFool(model, iters=3)[source]¶

‘DeepFool: A Simple and Accurate Method to Fool Deep Neural Networks’ [https://arxiv.org/abs/1511.04599]

Parameters:
  • model (nn.Module) – model to attack.
  • iters (int) – max iterations. (DEFALUT : 3)
Shape:
  • images: \((N, C, H, W)\) where N = number of batches, C = number of channels, H = height and W = width. It must have a range [0, 1].
  • labels: \((N)\) where each value \(y_i\) is \(0 \leq y_i \leq\) number of labels.
  • output: \((N, C, H, W)\).
Examples::
>>> attack = torchattacks.DeepFool(model, iters=3)
>>> adv_images = attack(images, labels)
forward(images, labels)[source]¶

Overridden.

BIM¶

class torchattacks.attacks.bim.BIM(model, eps=0.01568627450980392, alpha=0.00392156862745098, iters=0)[source]¶

BIM or iterative-FGSM in the paper ‘Adversarial Examples in the Physical World’ [https://arxiv.org/abs/1607.02533]

Parameters:
  • model (nn.Module) – model to attack.
  • eps (float) – strength of the attack or maximum perturbation. (DEFALUT : 4/255)
  • alpha (float) – step size. (DEFALUT : 1/255)
  • iters (int) – max iterations. (DEFALUT : 0)

Note

If iters set to 0, iters will be automatically decided following the paper.

Shape:
  • images: \((N, C, H, W)\) where N = number of batches, C = number of channels, H = height and W = width. It must have a range [0, 1].
  • labels: \((N)\) where each value \(y_i\) is \(0 \leq y_i \leq\) number of labels.
  • output: \((N, C, H, W)\).
Examples::
>>> attack = torchattacks.BIM(model, eps=4/255, alpha=1/255, iters=0)
>>> adv_images = attack(images, labels)
forward(images, labels)[source]¶

Overridden.

Step-LL¶

class torchattacks.attacks.stepll.StepLL(model, eps=0.01568627450980392, alpha=0.00392156862745098, iters=0)[source]¶

iterative least-likely class attack in the paper ‘Adversarial Examples in the Physical World’ [https://arxiv.org/abs/1607.02533]

Parameters:
  • model (nn.Module) – model to attack.
  • eps (float) – strength of the attack or maximum perturbation. (DEFALUT : 4/255)
  • alpha (float) – step size. (DEFALUT : 1/255)
  • iters (int) – max iterations. (DEFALUT : 0)

Note

If iters set to 0, iters will be automatically decided following the paper.

Shape:
  • images: \((N, C, H, W)\) where N = number of batches, C = number of channels, H = height and W = width. It must have a range [0, 1].
  • output: \((N, C, H, W)\).
Examples::
>>> attack = torchattacks.StepLL(model, eps=4/255, alpha=1/255, iters=0)
>>> adv_images = attack(images, labels)

Note

Step-ll dosen’t need any labels. However, for compatibility with other attacks, labels exists as input parameter in forward method. It is set to None by Default.

forward(images, labels=None)[source]¶

Overridden.

CW¶

class torchattacks.attacks.cw.CW(model, targeted=False, c=0.0001, kappa=0, iters=1000, lr=0.01)[source]¶

CW(L2) attack in the paper ‘Towards Evaluating the Robustness of Neural Networks’ [https://arxiv.org/abs/1608.04644]

Parameters:
  • model (nn.Module) – model to attack.
  • targeted (bool) – True - change image closer to a given label. False - change image away from a given label. (DEFALUT : False)
  • c (float) – c in the paper. parameter for box-constraint. (DEFALUT : 1e-4) \(minimize \Vert\frac{1}{2}(tanh(w)+1)-x\Vert^2_2+c\cdot f(\frac{1}{2}(tanh(w)+1))\)
  • kappa (float) – kappa (also written as ‘confidence’) in the paper. (DEFALUT : 0) \(f(x')=max(max\{Z(x')_i:i\neq t\} -Z(x')_t, - \kappa)\)
  • iters (int) – max iterations. (DEFALUT : 1000)
  • lr (float) – learning rate of the Adam optimizer. (DEFALUT : 0.01)

Warning

With default c, you can’t easily get adversarial images. Set higher c like 1.

Shape:
  • images: \((N, C, H, W)\) where N = number of batches, C = number of channels, H = height and W = width. It must have a range [0, 1].
  • labels: \((N)\) where each value \(y_i\) is \(0 \leq y_i \leq\) number of labels.
  • output: \((N, C, H, W)\).
Examples::
>>> attack = torchattacks.CW(model, targeted=False, c=1e-4, kappa=0, iters=1000, lr=0.01)
>>> adv_images = attack(images, labels)

Note

There are serveral NOT IMPLEMENTED part of the paper/other codes as follows :

  1. Binary search method for c : It costs too many times.
  2. Optimization on tanh space : Not in the paper, but in the other codes.
  3. Choosing method best l2 adversaries : It costs too many times.
forward(images, labels)[source]¶

Overridden.

R+FGSM¶

class torchattacks.attacks.rfgsm.RFGSM(model, eps=0.06274509803921569, alpha=0.03137254901960784, iters=1)[source]¶

‘Ensemble Adversarial Training : Attacks and Defences’ [https://arxiv.org/abs/1705.07204]

RFGSM = Random Noise Start + FGSM

Parameters:
  • model (nn.Module) – model to attack.
  • eps (float) – strength of the attack or maximum perturbation. (DEFALUT : 16/255)
  • alpha (float) – step size. (DEFALUT : 8/255)
  • iters (int) – max iterations. (DEFALUT : 1)
Shape:
  • images: \((N, C, H, W)\) where N = number of batches, C = number of channels, H = height and W = width. It must have a range [0, 1].
  • labels: \((N)\) where each value \(y_i\) is \(0 \leq y_i \leq\) number of labels.
  • output: \((N, C, H, W)\).
Examples::
>>> attack = torchattacks.RFGSM(model, eps=16/255, alpha=8/255, iters=1)
>>> adv_images = attack(images, labels)
forward(images, labels)[source]¶

Overridden.

PGD¶

class torchattacks.attacks.pgd.PGD(model, eps=0.3, alpha=0.00784313725490196, iters=40, random_start=False)[source]¶

PGD(Linf) attack in the paper ‘Towards Deep Learning Models Resistant to Adversarial Attacks’ [https://arxiv.org/abs/1706.06083]

Parameters:
  • model (nn.Module) – model to attack.
  • eps (float) – strength of the attack or maximum perturbation. (DEFALUT : 0.3)
  • alpha (float) – alpha in the paper. (DEFALUT : 2/255)
  • iters (int) – step size. (DEFALUT : 40)
  • random_start (bool) – using random initialization of delta. (DEFAULT : False)
Shape:
  • images: \((N, C, H, W)\) where N = number of batches, C = number of channels, H = height and W = width. It must have a range [0, 1].
  • labels: \((N)\) where each value \(y_i\) is \(0 \leq y_i \leq\) number of labels.
  • output: \((N, C, H, W)\).
Examples::
>>> attack = torchattacks.PGD(model, eps = 4/255, alpha = 8/255, iters=40, random_start=False)
>>> adv_images = attack(images, labels)
forward(images, labels)[source]¶

Overridden.

APGD (EOT + PGD)¶

class torchattacks.attacks.apgd.APGD(model, eps=0.3, alpha=0.00784313725490196, iters=40, sampling=10)[source]¶

Comment on “Adv-BNN: Improved Adversarial Defense through Robust Bayesian Neural Network” [https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.00895]

Parameters:
  • model (nn.Module) – model to attack.
  • eps (float) – strength of the attack or maximum perturbation. (DEFALUT : 0.3)
  • alpha (float) – step size. (DEFALUT : 2/255)
  • iters (int) – max iterations. (DEFALUT : 40)
  • sampling (int) – the number of models to sample. (DEFALUT : 100)
Shape:
  • images: \((N, C, H, W)\) where N = number of batches, C = number of channels, H = height and W = width. It must have a range [0, 1].
  • labels: \((N)\) where each value \(y_i\) is \(0 \leq y_i \leq\) number of labels.
  • output: \((N, C, H, W)\).
Examples::
>>> attack = torchattacks.APGD(model, eps = 4/255, alpha = 8/255, iters=40, sampling=100)
>>> adv_images = attack(images, labels)
forward(images, labels)[source]¶

Overridden.
